video.title: UML Diagrams Full Course (Unified Modeling Language)
video.description:
Learn about how to use UML diagrams to visualize the design of databases or systems. You will learn the most widely used Unified Modeling Language diagrams, their basic notation, and applications. UML diagrams are frequently used in software development.

Course from Ave Coders. Check out their channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCBvWPPieVSwyvfXvspW2vAg

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️ 
⌨️ (0:00:00) Course Introduction
⌨️ (0:02:50) Overview of the main Diagrams in UML 2.0
⌨️ (0:09:39) Class Diagram
⌨️ (0:17:43) Component Diagram
⌨️ (0:25:27) Deployment Diagram
⌨️ (0:31:49) Object Diagram
⌨️ (0:37:41) Package Diagram
⌨️ (0:45:07) Composite Structure Diagram
⌨️ (0:51:32) Profile Diagram
⌨️ (0:57:09) Use Case Diagram
⌨️ (1:04:29) Activity Diagram
⌨️ (1:10:08) State Machine Diagram
⌨️ (1:17:17) Sequence Diagram
⌨️ (1:26:12) Communications Diagram
⌨️ (1:33:57) Interaction Overview Diagram
⌨️ (1:37:11) Timing Diagram

🎉 Thanks to our Champion supporters:
👾 Otis Morgan
👾 DeezMaster
👾 Katia Moran 

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Lucas Groves
topLevelComment.text: The comments reflect a hideous reality of the modern world. Quality that is barely sufficient will be called "awesome!" and "amazing!" and anyone who objects to that absurdity will be howled down because, to avoid being labelled a HATER, you must offer lavish, exaggerated praise for things that, sadly, incorporate a fair amount of mediocrity. "During project analysis, you can create a class diagram to describe the structure of the system, and then create object diagrams to verify the accuracy and completeness of the class diagram. Prior to creating the class diagram, you can create an object diagram..." Come on, please. If that's some of "the BEST training in this field," I really wonder what poor quality looks like.

topLevelComment.author: Alex Davis
topLevelComment.text:
> one hour and a half video to explain uml? seriously?

a huge reason why cs courses can be so hard to learn, is because everyone is too technical. nearly every cs teacher tends to over-explain simple things that are already known, yet at the same time they overwhelm you with terms and symbols you haven't seen before without explaining them at all.

This narrator is defining each type of UML with terms and concepts that he hasn't given absolutely no context on. If you try and define a term with 7 new terms that haven't been defined then the reader/viewer won't understand.

How can you expect anyone to learn anything from this? Need to rethink your teaching/presentation format for this video.

replies.author: Moid Qureshi
replies.text: @Alex Davis Thank you very much for the detailed and very helpful pointers. Haven't used UML for a long time. Coming back to it for a specific task and I might working with it for a while, so wanted to refresh some of the basics. I'll try to keep these suggestions in mind while sifting through the information online.

replies.author: Alex Davis
replies.text:
@Moid Qureshi Unfortunately no, I didn't find any tutorial with a clear explanation. However I ended up learning it myself through Google searches, inference, and comparing sample diagrams. As it turns out, you don't need a video to explain this, you could learn it all in < 5 mins by reading an article.  Important things you should know:

Crows Foot, ERD, UML, Class Diagram, etc, these are all different names for basically the same thing. Even though their qualities aren't identical, all these terms get used interchangeably and there are very minor differences between them. 

*ERD*: an entity relationship diagram is ANY visual representation of a business or database. ERDs can have different notations, like crows foot or UML notation, but they are both still ERDs because they are visual diagrams. An ERD is literally just a visual diagram of the entities.

*Cardinality*: The relationship between any two entities. It can be represented by 1 to 1, 1 to many, or many to many.  

A payment and a receipt has a 1 to 1 relationship bc for each payment there is one and only one receipt, and for each receipt there is one and only one payment. Another example is a monogamous relationship, for 1 husband there is only 1 wife and vice versa.

A Mother to Son relationship is one to many because, a son can have only one mother, but the mother can birth many sons.

Many to many relationship: Student and Class, because each student can have many classes and each class can have many students.

*Crows Foot*: The thing that looks like this >-----< or like this --||-----< or something similar. Its a quick and easy way to visually represent cardinality. >--< is many to many, -||--||- is one to one, >--||- is one to many, -o--< is zero to many, etc.

*UML class diagram*: Exactly the same thing as an ERD, but NOT using crows foot notation. Instead of crows foot, it uses *numbers* to show cardinality. For example 1 is one and only one. 0..1 is zero or one, 1...* Is one or many, etc.

There's also something called *chen notation* which is the most simplified version of the ERD of them all. In Chen notation you don't need to list any attributes, PKs, FKs... It's consist purely of the entities and the cardinalities.

There is a dense amount of information... it's super technical and wordy but often times its much more simple than it seems.  Try to filter out the unnecessary information and retain only the most important concepts . Make sure you understand all the different notations, primary and foreign keys, cardinality, inheritance, functional dependence/independence, and normalization up to 3NF. Conceptually it's not difficult to grasp, and one you learn all that you can finally start with SQL which is a LOT less boring 🎉😂

topLevelComment.author: Pablo Fonseca
topLevelComment.text:
14:46

I think is not necessary to have a Square and a Rectangle shape if both have the same properties and specifications, if both are the same I could create just a Rectangle class cause the difference between Square and Rectangle is that Square has equivalent sides, so I could use the Rectangles class. Even Java API for Swing has the same implementation for Rectangle2D, they didn't specify a Square2D class.
